summary: Jojo is a lonely German boy who discovers that his single mother is hiding a Jewish girl in their attic. Aided only by his imaginary friend -- Adolf Hitler -- Jojo must confront his blind nationalism as World War II continues to rage on.

To make a Nazi satire is daring. To make a Nazi satire centered around a child is even more so. And to give that same child an imaginary version of Hitler as a best friend is just wild. To call Jojo Rabbit "offbeat" would be an understatement. It's a hilarious foray into the final chapter of WWII that doesn't shy away from the heavier things throughout. The performances are enchanting, whether it's the titular star played by Roman Griffin Davis, or his Jewish-sympathizing mother played by the always excellent Scarlett Johansson. There's also noteworthy turns as a Nazi officers by both Sam Rockwell and Rebel Wilson. It is, however, relative newcomer Archie Yates that steals every scene that he's in as the hilarious Yorki, another Hitler Youth member. Yorki serves as the audience's morality, always asking or stating the obviously absurd to ensure that he's heard the nonsense correctly. The characters are certainly what sell this whacky story that gets more and more serious as the movie plays out. Johansson's son discovers that his mother is hiding a Jewish girl in a crawl space in their home and is faced with having to decide between his mother's judgement and the Führer's. As the film progresses it reminds us that it's not a straight-comedy and does, impressively, own up to its serious subject matter amid the relative silliness. Taika Waititi continues to prove that he's the go-to name in oddball comedy, while also showing that he can deftly tell a serious story so long as it's wrapped in his signature absurdity.

Initially, this movie made me feel uncomfortable. I thought the only way it would be acceptable is if the director, Taika Waititi, was Jewish because a non-Jewish director would have no business making a comedy about the Holocaust. After a quick Google search, I discovered that TW actually is Jewish. Sigh of relief. It's now safe to laugh at Funny Hitler. Such a brilliant movie. So bizarre, so hilarious, so incredibly smart.

The courage it takes to kick, for the 100th time, the dead body of an enemy vanquished almost a century ago. And the audacity it takes to think that it somehow makes you original, funny or transgressive. And the boomerish boredom of it all.

Yes, most of us know that Nazis are bad. But having seen one movie too many banging on about it with oh-so-serious aplomb has become pretty tedious. Enter Jojo Rabbit, which takes an entirely different approach from the perspective of a young boy being indoctrinated into the Nazi Youth, who gradually comes to realise the errors of his ways, though repeatedly challenged by his imaginary (and, to begin with, hilarious) pal Adolph Hitler. The satire, the pathos and the terror are spot on in their own way. Not since The Producers has Hitler looked so ridiculous. I laughed out loud, I was saddened by the reality of war portrayed, and I even welled up a little at the end (and it takes a lot for a movie to do that to me). And excellent performances throughout. Highly recommended.

A young boy in Hitler's army (whose has the Fuhrer as his imaginary friend) finds out his mother is hiding a Jewish girl in their home…. Who would have thought that a lampoon of Nazi ideology could be so thought provoking? The experience of "Jojo Rabbit" represents a roller coaster of emotions. It is funny, heart-warming, heartbreaking and quirky. It's unique, not just due to its controversial subject matter and approach but is so much more than that in the way it takes you from hilarity to heartbreak. And the cast is fantastic in taking you along for the ride, especially Archie Yates as Yorkie, Jojos boyhood best friend.

Taika Waititi plays Hitler like a tall tale character in "Jojo Rabbit", a film that satirizes a coming of age story during the Nazi regime in World War II. Laugh-out-loud funny, endearing, and heartbreaking, Waititi (director of the great vampire parody "What We Do in the Shadows" and the first episode of "The Mandalorian") has directed the feel good movie of the year, a shattering morality tale, a hilarious well-written spoof, and a powerful tale of innocence and tolerance. Roman Griffin Davis gives a gripping debut and one of the best child performances as Jojo and Scarlett Johansson is tender and rousing in an Oscar-worthy performance as his mother Rosie. At times the film might feel like it's trying to explore too many ideas, but this is a rare movie that manages to effectively create a comedy about Nazisms and the blindness of following mislead conformity.

As unlikely as it sounds, Taika Waititi's Jojo Rabbit is a comedy about Nazism, fanaticism, the horrors of war, tyranny, compassion, acceptance and a 10-year-old boy with an imaginary friend by the name of Adolf Hitler.  In the movie, young Jojo (Roman Griffin Davis) and his mother (Scarlett Johansson), a resistance fighter, try to survive in war-torn Germany towards the end of WW2, all while illegally harboring a Jewish girl (Thomasin McKenzie) behind the walls of their home.  It is a film filled with gentle humor and pathos, a bold satire that skewers everything that gets in its path.  The cast is excellent, the story is original, the characters are interesting and the writing is incredibly clever.  Jojo Rabbit is one of those rare movies that can make an audience laugh and cry at the same time.

This is very much a quirky watch, which has a strong comic book type feel to it, in that there's quite strong colours and settings, with somewhat exaggerated characters (in terms of their gestures and behaviour). Its obviously a very serious subject, the 2nd World War and I wouldn't want to downplay that at all but there is a certain, very dark comedy element to this film I suppose. Of course there's a fair argument to say that this may make some people think that you can have a laugh at what was a mass scale tragedy, genocide of the Jews etc. and I'm also very much aware of the rise in antisemitism in recent months and years.

I think the humour comes from the way it clearly shows just how obsessive the Nazi's were and the clear megalomania that was present. Its very much satirical and features some interesting cast members as supporting characters, like Rebel Wilson and Stephen Merchant. The fact that the film focusses on such a young child (a 10 year old) and how he tries to get his head around what is happening around him and why, that's quite good in that it perhaps could be seen as a bit insightful into how the native children may have processed things. Its very much tongue in cheek and I can understand why it would annoy or upset some but I do feel there's something interesting about it. I'm glad it has the 12 rating in the UK, as I wouldn't be keen for pretty young kids to watch it, with the obvious themes, even though there is relatively little in the way of violence, or graphic violence certainly.

It is somewhat outrageous in tone at times, mainly with the scenes featuring Jojo's imaginary friend, Hitler himself (played by Taika Waititi), who gestures and behaves in a very childish way. Its a bit strange but I quite liked it in a way, though I can understand those who don't feel that way. I couldn't quite understand how it was anti-nationalism until quite late on in the film but it did feel fairly effective by the very end.

Personally, I'd recommend it as long as you know what its about and the type of film it is (a quirky darkly comic/satire drama).

JoJo Rabbit is a very interesting war film, using comedy to convey the majority of their story. And as much as it is a war film, and they do have many examples of historically accurate moments, such as the Hitler youth at the start of the movie, the Gestapo who come to search JoJo's house, the propaganda campaigns that JoJo pastes around their town, and even the public hangings, that's not really the main focus of the film. What they are really trying to convey is less about the events and the war, more about what it brings out in us as people when we go through hardships. It sends a message of love and connection, and acceptance of everyone, despite the differences of race and looks. It also sends a message of how easily we can be brainwashed and manipulated by people with power. The character development throughout the film also shows us a story of growing up, and leaving the innocence of childhood behind us, this idea is presented in the scene where JoJo chases after the blue butterfly, showing he is still a young kid, innocent and childish. They use that in an interesting way, and instead of keeping with the beauty and freeness throughout the scene, use it as more of a juxtaposition, showing JoJo, chasing the butterfly through the square, only to look up and find his mother hung, dead. Another interesting thing in that scene is the camera angle they use as JoJo clutches onto his mother's feet, and they have a rather despairing yet symbolic moment as he tries to tie up her shoelaces. At the start of the movie, everything is quite happy and bright, the image being highly saturated to bring out the colour, however as the movie wears on we get darker and gloomier scenes, with less and less saturation and colour. Overall it is a great film, with a heartfelt message and likeable yet complex characters that I really enjoyed.

Jojo Rabbit is honestly an excellent movie. Within it, there is a huge range of emotions for the audience to experience as they watch. It's a lovely, light-hearted movie surrounding a brainwashed young boy living in Nazi Germany and truly captures a glimpse of what it might have been like in Germany by the end of the war. 
It does have plenty of historically accurate references within it such as the Hitler Youth, the Gestapo, public hangings and plenty of others. And such a nice film about such a horrible subject can't come without some serious/emotional moments.
I feel the overall message of the film was to show what can happen when those in power spread their opinions to thousands of followers, how easily people can be discriminated against and targeted because of it and how a person can finally see another side to a second's story.
A sweet, heartwarming film, I would recommend.

I think it's safe to say that this film isn't a subtle and brilliant piece. The acting was often sub-par, with some questionable German accents in there. The themes and perspectives were highly simplistic and over-explained. On top of all this, there were parts that felt dull and unnecessary, and a few moments of pure cringe. The dragging out of the beginning and end, limiting the film's effect, is a perfect example of this. However, despite it's obvious flaws, Jojo Rabbit provided a fresh and clever critique of the flawed ideologies that underpinned Nazi Germany. It was charming, funny, and all-in-all, a movie that I thoroughly enjoyed.

Another prime example of cinema at its finest and another reason 2019 continues to be one of the best years for films. Jojo rabbit is a blend of humor and heart. Comedic satire that has one dying of laughter and a story that pulls on your heart, makes one cry a river, and captivates the meaning and message of the film. Taika Waititi knew how to tackle such a heavy and tragic event in our history. The plot development, the storyline, and its screenplay were executed well. Standout performances from main characters Roman Griffin Davis, Thomasin Mackenzie, and Taika himself to minor roles such as Rockwell, Wilson, and Allen. A truly beautiful and heartfelt story. Jojo rabbit perfectly balances telling a realistic and tragic story about world war 2 whilst still managing to deliver on some wholesome comedy and managing to get its message across all while doing so. The dynamic between imaginary Adolf Hitler and Jojo is at first a lot of fun but the further along the movie gets, the more we start to see the serious and dramatic repercussions of what indoctrinations can do to young children. It's these kinds of things that make this movie amazing. The brother sister dynamic between Jojo and Elsa is phenomenal. Both of them have lost everything but over the course of the movie, they find friendship in each other and perhaps more, perhaps even family. And if a certain death scene isn't touching, only Taika Waititi could tug at out heart strings like that. The pure raw emotion shown in a few seconds is just magical. I could keep going on about why this movie is such a masterpiece, its beautiful way of telling an informative story about history whilst still having respect for the original events, its enlightening themes or even the cinematography and costume design. It all comes together like a beautiful tapestry. Another perfect example of how genius of a filmmaker Taika Waititi truly is.

I don't even think 100% is a score that does this film justice, but that's where I have to pitch my score. It's genius. The end scene (incl. score) had me almost bawling uncontrolably.

An absolutely phenomenal piece of cinema! I might never have been touched in those many emotions in any film I've ever watched, and yes, this was one memorable experience!
Jojo finds that his mother is hiding a Jewish girl in the house, and his life takes a twist. He realizes true human nature, and the consequences of hate.
While being a strong "Hate-Satire", this film works extremely well as a comedy it was supposed to be. There are so many interesting elements which set the base for some good laughs, for example Jojo's imaginary friend Hitler. He is absolutely delightful to be on screen, and almost the entire time he is, its fun time!
The acting by all the characters is amazing, and the leads use their talent and the strongly written script to absolutely hit the wow mark.
The story is simple enough, but what makes this film special is the focus on the theme. It is wonderful to have films like these which target teens and adults alike, and deliver the respective message to those who can process it. Very clever indeed.
Now, talking about the emotion, the film is funny, romantic, sad, depressing, chilling, makes you have a sense of realization, and more. It clearly shows the mindset and passion of a child and how dedicated he is to hos cause, but it all changes once he sees it in real life, and makes him question the reason why that thing is even happening. He learns for himself what is right and what is wrong. Don't let people make you judge something. You will have to see for yourself.
Overall, a beautiful, finely paced film that will make you cherish every moment, or at least it did for me!

99/100. An emotional movie movie that portrays the indoctrination of Nazi Germany's youth during WWII in a satirical yet serious way. Taika Waititi did an excellent job of telling a story that can often be very difficult to tell. The acting performances were outstanding, especially from Roman Griffin Davis and Scarlett Johansson, making you really feel the dynamic between a loving mother and her son. I did not know what to expect going into this movie as I was hesitant to turn it on given the source material, but I am very glad I went with Jojo Rabbit.

Eccentric strategy when approaching Nazism from the perspective of a ten-year-old boy, who believes he is a Nazi, but when he meets the Jewess that his mother hid in a place in the house, he learns to think for himself and to question everything he has. trained. The whole approach of the film is delicate, but firm. The humor present in the film does not overlap with the essential drama that the story carries. The film tells us: "More love and less hate". And after I finished watching, I felt for those who couldn't have a happy ending.

Jojo Rabbit - 8.5/10. Jojo Rabbit is a film that needs to be seen in its entirety to understand its overall moral and theme. If you decide to leave halfway or at the beginning of the film due to it's comedic content, well you're missing out. Jojo Rabbit is a film that deals with a heavy subject in a light manner for the first half of the film. There's the absurdity of Taika Waititi's performance, and some of the jokes happen to walk the thin line of funny and "oh my god." Roman Griffin Davis who plays the lead character does a great job of delivering a characterization of a young boy who is unaware of the horrors that are being committed by the very group he wants to join. His eventual friendship with the young woman that his mother (played delightfully by Scarlett Johansson) helps change his viewpoint on what the war is really about. The film takes a more serious tone as the plot goes on, and it takes some interesting turns for a comedy. Comedy helps us deal with certain subjects which are sometimes impossible to deal or listen to. Taika does a fine job of showing how this world would be viewed by a young child, and also does an amazing job of showing how that child grows out of hate by choosing to follow love. Go watch the film! It's definitely a deep comedy film, and probably will divide some people in terms of the way they take the satire. But in my opinion, its a story that needed to be told.

7.75/10. Taika Waititi's eccentric brand of melding heart and humor is on full display in 'JoJo Rabbit.' He writes, directs, and stars in this picture - I wouldn't discourage someone who hasn't been a fan of his work from watching, but it has his fingerprints all over it, so you know what to expect. It is filled with youthful spirit and sweetness, derived from the performances of its young leads; Roman Griffin Davis is JoJo, a scrappy runt determined to climb the ranks of the Hitler Youth who is surprised to find a mysterious young jewish girl named Elsa, played by Thomasin McKenzie, living in his walls. Though he does his best to be a model, hateful Nazi, JoJo can't overcome his curiosity as he begins learning about Elsa (though he justifies his getting to know her as reconnaissance). He is a boy in search of identity, and though he started finding one in the Hitler Youth movement, it had not been fully baked into his being – Elsa, and his interactions with his friends and leaders of the Hitler Youth, often leave him in a place of contradicting feelings and beliefs as he attempts to reconcile the hate he has learned with the gentle kindness he feels in his heart. Davis and McKenzie sell this journey of self-discovery with ranging performances that brim with sincerity, humor, fear, and hope. They are supported by some great performances from the adults in the cast, particularly Scarlett Johannsen as JoJo's secretly-Nazi-hating mother, Sam Rockwell who portrays the Nazi offer that leads the Hitler Youth, and Waititi as JoJo's imaginary friend, Hitler. It is a bit problematic, especially in our current cultural context, that Nazis are portrayed in such humorous manner, but it's worth noting the undercurrent of devastation and fear that lies hardly beneath the surface, especially whenever we see Elsa come out of the wall, or in some later anxiety-fueling scenes where Nazis come to JoJo's house to find Elsa. Waititi may make rib on some prominent Nazi figures and the absurd cruelty of their ideology, but he never makes light of the horrors that their victims endured. It is that constant shadow of atrocity that grounds this comedy, and what makes JoJo's quest for identity all the more satisfying by film's end. It certainly has Waititi's (arguably, and I'd argue against this characterization) over-the-top stamp on it, but it also has a likeable cast, a good heart, and a message that is in these times certainly worth hearing.

Love the sense of humour and wit Taika Waititi injects into all his  projects and interviews alike.   This movie is both funny and witty, but I wouldn't term it an outright comedy as it does deal with weighty issues.

The main character Jojo is a 10 year old and the product of the time he was living in.  His hero and biggest influence being Hitler and Nazism during WW2, making him enthusiastic to join the Hitler youth, typical of the kids of his country at the time.

This movie is very clever at taking us along with the innocent child who has no reason to disagree with the indoctrination by his government.  At first seeing how he gets along joining these people and the humour of the situations and characters he meets.

Woven through though is a subtle unease that grows as his eyes are opened more and more, challenging his indoctrination and shading the movies tone incrementally darker to the end.

As an adult knowing all the facts about the time, I began to feel a type of claustrophobia for the characters due to the danger  faced by opposing or being seen to oppose any part of the doctrine.  

The movie is light enough at the start for anyone to watch, (not being put off by a documentary style war film).   It does not suffer from stereotypical invading Nazi hordes obviously as this is their country.  It is more subtle, showing the propaganda the ordinary person had to live with whether they bought in to it or not.  These are people who must have lived ordinary lives before extremists took power, then began a war, inflicting horrific consequences for those not upholding their ridiculous beliefs.  

The reality of what kids had to go through in war hit home gently with the dawning of Jojo. We are not hit over the head with tragedy and sombre tones and colours. The weight of the subject matter is beautifully shaded in over the length of the movie, keeping in perfect tone and in my view making it a very enjoyable movie.

 My daughter, who was roughly the same age as Jojo at time of first viewing, was introduced to the harrowing issues of WW2 in the most accessible way that made her ask questions and want to know more.

There are notable issues with its admittedly ambitious tonal juggling act, which sometimes come across as jarring and distracting. However, that is not enough to offset the entire film, which from start to finish is a gorgeously shot, beautifully designed, sharply written, wryly funny, and emotionally engaging satire. It plays as both a subversive ode to over-the-top wartime propaganda and as a thoughtful and mature exploration of the absurdity of war and the euphoria of freedom and liberation.

Roman Griffin Davis gives one of the best child performances of the decade as the titular Jojo, delivering charm, heart, and charisma. Thomasina McKenzie continues to solidify her image as someone to continue looking out for. Scarlett Johannson deserves props for trying something new, and making it work. Taika Waititi does well as a mockery of Adolf Hitler, though his work behind the camera is definitely more impressive and commendable. A standout performance would be Sam Rockwell, whose role in the film was unexpectedly important but ultimately turned out to be heartfelt and enjoyable.

The cinematography and production design was just amazing to look at. The costume work was also very well-crafted.

Overall, Jojo Rabbit hits way more often than it misses, of which there are few and far in between. Strong performances, palpable emotion, a lovely visual aesthetic, and a challenging exploration of touchy themes help make it one of the more interesting releases of 2019.
Heart, humor and tragedy are all executed at a very high level. Good performances, good concept. Shows Nazi Germany with nuance that ultimately never excuses it.

A fantastic film! You come for the goofball comedy with a silly version of Hitler and stay engrossed in the real drama on presentation. Is it deep and game-changing? No, it has its fair share of WWII tropes. It isn't trying to reinvent the wheel by any means. But that's the inherent appeal. It's modern and fresh, and not burdened by how WWII films should be presented. Evil nazis? They're literally buffoonish comedy characters. Hitler youth? It's like a goofy summer camp for kids. And yet, despite this comedic reframing, the film doesn't try to color over or dodge the true awfulness of the war, in all its context. By the end you wouldn't be remiss if you forgot you were watching a comedy. And that's the key to new views of old, "traditional" subject matter for films to cover; the reframing itself is the entertainment, and without restriction, you can explore the topic in any way you choose.

Jojo Rabbit dares to compete with Robert Benigni's Life Is Beautiful (1997) and comes away looking very accomplished.  

As reviewers have noted, JoJo commits more to Monty Python than it commits to being a dedicated dramatic-comedy.  Life Is Beautiful is a rare 10/10 in this category (updating Chaplin creatively and effectively).  

JoJo has a wealth of assets:  the lead child actor, the wonderful visual framing of many shots, vibrant colors and wardrobe, Scarlet Johanson, Sam Rockwell and Rebel Wilson all contributing significantly, plus several twists and turns keeping  audiences from settling into tropes, cliches, and/or sentimentality.  
It's pretty great.  FYI two online articles comparing Jojo Rabbit with Life Is Beautiful:

"Jojo Rabbit and Life Is Beautiful use the same contrasting narrative tools — Nazi Germany and a child's perspective"  at firstpost.com

Jojo Rabbit is about a ten year German boy in Hitler's army training to be a soldier during the final years of WWII. Roman Griffin Davis plays the little boy who finds out that his mother played by Scarlett Johansson was hiding a Jewish girl in their home. Director Taika Waititi brought a creatively sad and humorous storyline to life and he acted as the protagonist Adolf in Jojo's mind. During a time of tragedy and horror, humanity shows love always prevails even during time of war. Sam Rockwell, Rebel Wilson, Alfie Allen, and Stephen Merchant round up the supporting German cast. The movie was nominated for multiple Oscar and it won the award for Best Adopted Screenplay. The storyline will make you laugh, cry, and make you mad but overall it was a great movie with a great script and wonder actors.  Definitely add this to your list.

Review: Jojo Rabbit is an absolute must-see, due to its eccentric tone, hilarious but not in your face jokes, stellar performances (Scarlett Johansson got an Oscar) and surprisingly dark and heart-breaking moments. The way Takia Watiti blends callbacks and metaphors into the script - the butterflies, shoes, stare an lion in the eye, etc. - is genius, making rewatches worth it, and the saitre is there, but not in front of character or story. The first 10 minutes are funny but disjointed, but from there it's a roller-coaster of laughs and emotions, with Roman Griffin-Davis and Thomasin McKenzie putting in incredible, emotionally powerful performances, while Waitit himself as Hitler, along with AA perfect supporting cast, make it a beautiful satire that could become a classic. | Grade: A

World War II is a tired, well-trodden landscape, but this film felt wholly original. Near-farcical comedy involving Hitler and Nazis could easily become uncomfortable or inappropriate with sloppy writing, but the film puts out a thick, constant stream of satire immediately, leaving no room for ambiguity with the viewer. Fun, funny and poignant.
An astonishing mix of comic, emotional, and dramatic moments

This is a fantastic film, the focus is Jojo the 10 year old boy and all that a 10 year wants to fit in and has to do to try to make sense of the world. The WWII and Nazi setting is really in the end incidental, its the very challenging backdrop to examine these themes, just the vehicle for examining that. This is especially obvious when you consider this in the context of Taika Waititi's brilliant other films about boys facing the same confusions - Boy; The Hunt for the Wilderpeople... Hitler was a rock star and the opening of JoJo Rabbit, with the fuhrer exiting planes and waving to adoring fans all set to The Beatles' "Komm, gib mir deine Hand" ("I Want to Hold Your Hand") was funny and terrifying all at once. In fact, Hitler was such a star that he captured the imaginations of German youth to the point where Johannes "JoJo" (Roman Griffin Davis) conjures him as an imaginary friend (Taika Waititi) — that's where this adventure begins. It's funny, but dark, as JoJo is thrust into the dilemma of supporting his beloved Germany — in the indoctrinated, Hitler Youth kind of love — and reporting the Jewish girl (Thomasin McKenzie) stowed away in his sister's old room to the authorities, or keeping his mouth shut, as doing so will protect his mother's (Scarlett Johansson) and hers. Elsa's "Lessons on the Jew," again, toe the line between hilarious and frightening, as JoJo takes the outlandish statements — from the well-known "Jews have horns," to the lesser-known "Jews live underground" — as absolute fact. Let's talk about Hitler. Waititi's performance as the silly side-kick of JoJo's imagination is commendable, and I especially enjoyed the gag of him constantly offering his young friend a cigarette. The scene where Hitler is lying in JoJo's bed, as "friend's keep their friend's beds warm" was probably the best line. Hitler does take a back seat the second half of the film, which I think was a smart move as it let the seriousness set in and silliness subside. Sam Rockwell as Captain Klenzendorf, the alcoholic Nazi officer and youth camp director has the single funniest moment as he finally gets to showcase his Elton John-like battle uniforms as the Allies come closin' in. His second-in-command and secret gay-lover, Finkle (Alfie Allen (Theon from GoT)) did seem like a waste, as he barely had a single line. Of course, the film is far from just a satire with childish Nazis and touches on the very real, very futile resistance movement ordinary German people took up against the Third Reich with JoJo's mother, Elsa — if you're interested in the topic, I recently read Han Fallada's excellent novel, Every Man Dies Alone. When you see those red shoes again… it's a gut-punch, if I've ever felt one. JoJo Rabbit takes dark point in history — and an actual book on hitlerjugend "Caging Skies" — adds an original spin, and somehow makes it fun without losing the importance of the message.

Taika Waititi manages to successfully balance comedy and heavy subject matter in this World War II satire. Jojo Rabbit is one of those films that will run you through the mill of emotions. It will make you laugh and it may even make you cry. One thing that this film benefits from is its charm. The relationship between both Roman Griffin Davis and Scarlett Johansson's character is really charming. All the performances in this film are strong; Sam Rockwell is great and Taika Waititi plays a satirical version of Hitler and pulls it off nicely. There are many sudden tonal shifts but Waititi manages to pull that off too. I don't have many issues with Jojo Rabbit; sometimes the pacing felt a little off but other than that this is a very well executed film that I would definitely recommend, especially if you are a fan of satires and/or comedy-dramas.

It was going to be tough, making a film about the Nazi youth where the young protagonist's imaginary friend is Hitler himself. Adding that it is to be a comedy satire must have felt like a pretty daunting task. 

What Taika Waititi has done with Jojo Rabbit is nothing short of spectacular. The comedy moments are handled exceptionally as Jojo, a young boy in theHitler youth begins an unlikely  friendship with Elsa, the young Jewish girl who his mother is hiding within the walls of their house.

The young cast of Roman Griffin Davis as Jojo, Archie Yates as Yorki, Jojo's loveable friend, and absolute star in the making Thomasin Mckenzie as Elsa are all fantastic in what is a movie that will make up feel every emotion throughout. Sam Rockwell is excellent, Scarlett Johansson's performance as Jojo's mother deserved just as much recognition her outing in Marriage Story.

You can tell Waititi put everything into this movie and handled the subject matter with respect and has brought all of us a perfectly crafted story of Heartbreak, Growth, Love and Hope.

I JUST FINISHED WATCHING THIS MOVIE. 
I DOWNLOADED IT MONTHS BEFORE AND I KIND OF JUST FORGET ABOUT IT, I HEARD OF IT BEING A GOOD MOVIE, THAT'S WHY I DOWNLOADED IT.  
BUT IT'S A MOVIE ABOUT WAR AND KID, WHICH I HATE BOTH. 

AS I STARTED WATCHING, I COULD NOT STOP. I COULD NOT HOLD BACK MY TEARS WHEN JO JO FELT BUTTERFLIES FLYING IN HIS STOMACH FOR THE FIRST TIME HE REALIZE WHAT LOVE IS.  

WE COULD NOT CHANGE THE WAY WE VE BEEN EDUCATED AND THE CULTURE BACKGROUND WE HAD, BUT UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SHOULD WE FORGET THAT WE ARE LOVED AND WE HAVE THE ABILITY TO LOVE. LOVE OPENS UP A WINDOW, THROUGH IT WE COULD HAVE A CHANCE TO SEE THE WORLD IN OUR OWN EYES. AND LEARN IT IN OUR OWN WAYS.

I FEEL LIKE THAT'S THE MESSAGE I RECEIVED.

IN ORDER TO SEND THIS MESSAGE, THE MOVIE PRESENTS THE WHOLE STORY THROUGH JOJO, A TEN YEARS OLD BOY'S EYES, SO WE CAN FEEL RELATED, AND UNDERSTAND JOJO'S (PEOPLE'S ) FANTASY ABOUT BEING IN NAZI'S ARMY, AND WE CAN ALSO KNOW ABOUT, IN THE MEANWHILE, PEOPLE LIKE JOJO'S MOM WERE WILLING TO RISK THEIR LIFVES TO HELP PEOPLE AND STICK TO THEIR BELIEFS UNDER THAT DIFFICULT CIRCUMSTANCES. 

I APPRECIATE HOW SHE WAS STILL PROTECTING HER SON'S WORLD, EDUCATE HIM IN A GENTLE WAY WITH HUMOR WHENEVER HIS IDEA COME INTO CONFLICT WITH HERS, SHE NEVER JUST SAY: YOU ARE WRONG, I AM RIGHT, YOU SHOULD LISTEN TO ME. SHE GAVE THE SPACE AND TIME TO HIM, LISTEN TO HIM, RESPECT HIM, DESPITE HE IS A LITTLE BOY.

AND ALSO THE DIRECTOR MADE A GREAT BALANCE IN THE CRUEL WORLD OF WAR AND THE INNOCENT WORLD OF A CHILD, HE DIDN'T JUST HIDES THE CRUELNESS, THERE ARE BOMBS AND DEAD SOLIDERS EVERYWHERE, BUT HE CAPTURED JOJO MOM'S DEATH IN A WAY THAT WE COULD FEEL THE HEARTBREAK --- JOJO HOLDING HIS MOMS FEET IN HIS ARMS, WE KNOW THAT SHE HAD BEEN HANGED, BUT WE NEVER SEE IT ENTIRELY IN MOVIE, JUST BY THESE PAIR OF SHOSE, WE COULD BE FEELING THE PAIN OF JOJO LOOSEING HIS MOM. AND DURING JOJO'S CONVERSATIONS WITH THE JEWISH GIRL ELSA AND HIS FRIEND YORKI, WE COULD ALWAYS SEE HOPE DESPITE HATE AND MADENESS IN THE WORLD. 

THE MOVIE COULD GO TO THE EXTREME TO DESTROY IT ALL, BUT IT LEFT HOPE FOR US AUDIENCE, MAYBE THERE IS A BETTER WAY TO ALWAYS MEMORIZE THE HISTOTY WITHOUT FILL OUR HEARTS WITH HATE.

JUST LIKE THE END OF THE MOVIE SAID:
LET EVERY THING HAPPEN TO YOU
BEAUTY AND TERROR
JUST KEEP GOING
NO FEELING IS FINAL

I always find it funny when the audience review significantly supersedes the 'critic review'. Honestly this movie is beautiful, it's funny and silly, and at points ridiculous, but also moving and beautiful. Taika Waititi has a way of creating movies that retrospectively are purely entertaining...and when you look back on them there are so many laughable moments that you reflect on it as a comedy, but when you watch it again (which you'll always want to do with anything he's written); Suddenly you're moved..! Moved deeply!! This was another one, the performances were amazing, the pace was perfect and the script was incredibly moving. I loved this movie!! It is beautiful but vulnerable, its shows the strength of humanity, but also our vulnerability to manipulation. If you haven't watch this movie yet, please do. You'll be a different person afterwards!! It shows our humanity and how easily we are moved to despise those different to us. In this day and age it's more relevant than ever, please watch this movie!!

This is a great little offbeat comedy about a little German boy, growing up in the 1940s, who is obsessed by his hero, Adolf Hitler. This strange premise for a comedy really works and is a brilliant, tongue-in-cheek study into the ludicrous nature of hero worship. 
Little Jojo has a wonderfully innocent approach to his life and has imaginary conversations with Hitler who is brilliantly and comply realised by Taika Waititi who also wrote and directed the movie. Life is turned upside down for Jojo when he discovers that his glamorous, Nazi mother (Scarlett Johansson) is hiding a little Jewish girl in the attic room.
Touching, moving and very funny, the movie is carried by the brilliant performance of Roman Griffin Davis as Jojo but I also loved Archie Yates as Yorki, his little friend who is equally naive and unsuited to the Hitler Youth movement and a brilliant supporting performance by Rebel Wilson as a youth camp leader who is sadistic and awful. 
This is a true gem of a movie and very worth seeking out.

Remarkably well done.  When I first saw the trailer for this, I thought 'hard pass' - another brave Hollywood movie taking shots at Nazis - what courage!  But the film has almost nothing to do with Nazis.  Sure, it is set in WWII Germany, but Hitler and Nazism is just a frame of reference to tell a story about fitting in and coming of age.  Perhaps the writer even thought of it as a parable and warning to future generations.  Even now, some 75 years later, everyone in the audience gets the Hitler jokes - it is a shared frame of reference.  What would you do if you so desperately wanted to belong, you would do things that seemed unimaginable to you and your loved ones?  Would you proceed?  Or would your sense of humanity pull you back from the brink?  The Hitler shtick is there to show us the correct answer, but "the line separating good and evil passes not through states, nor between classes, nor between political parties either, but right through every human heart" - Solzhenitsyn (I had to look that up).  This movie is almost wildly optimistic, I fear, as we may ourselves face something like this in our future.  And odds are, we would go along with the herd, even though we felt in our heart it was wrong.

There were few winners but plenty of losers in WW2 as there are in Jojo Rabbit.  This movie is full of 'losers' and not only the ones that make bad choices and stuff up their's and everyone's lives but also those who experience real loss perpetuated by the biggest 'losers' of all time, Nazis.  Seeing this movie through a 10 years olds eyes drives home the pointlessness of this war.  It left me with an increased sense of frustration as to how something like this (WW2)  can happen in the first place.  Young Jojo highlights this in a way that only child like innocence can.  I have always held onto a sense reverence when discussing WW2 and this movie undoubtedly challenged this mindset.  In the end I was a bit lost not sure whether I enjoyed the movie or not but the sign of many good movies is that you are left thinking about them long after the credits are done.  The acting and visuals are superb.

Cut from the same unsavory mismatched tonality as LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL, JOJO RABBIT is a wholly misguided fusion of an exceptional movie and an atrocious one. There’s something to be said for the adage “mock the Devil and he will flee from thee”, but even someone as jocular as me has to concede that some things demand to be treated as sacred, and the slaughter of millions of Jewish people under the Nazi regime surely has to be chief among them. When JOJO RABBIT approaches its mission objective with the gravitas it warrants, it typically resonates (even with an over-reliance on cutesy Hollywood moments), but even more abysmally and offensively than his derailment of the THOR franchise into silly sitcom yucks, director Taika Waititi indulges in dozens of moments of whimsical, flippant and grossly inappropriate comedy (this film surely must possess the most schizophrenic tonal shifts of any I’ve ever seen) that are made even worse by the fact that, unlike THOR: RAGNAROK, almost none of the jokes land. Perhaps if the comedy served as some kind of method to elevate or enrich the material, it could be forgiven, but I see no richer layer of commentary in any of its cartoonish excess. There’s a lovely message at the heart of JOJO RABBIT, but it’s buried under such a cruel disrespect of the very history it chooses to honor that the whole thing ends up feeling rather shameful and somewhat sickening, with its heart in the right place, but its head anywhere but.
A heartbreaking, beautifully directed, and heartwarming film, JoJo Rabbit will have you sobbing in some scenes, and crying with laughter at others.

7.75/10. Taika Waititi's eccentric brand of mixing heart and humor is on full display in 'JoJo Rabbit.' He writes, directs, and stars in this picture - I wouldn't discourage someone who hasn't been a fan of his work from watching, but it has his fingerprints all over it, so you know what to expect. It is filled with youthful spirit and sweetness, derived from the performances of its young leads; Roman Griffin Davis is JoJo, a scrappy runt determined to climb the ranks of the Hitler Youth who is surprised to find a mysterious young jewish girl named Elsa, played by Thomasin McKenzie, living in his walls. Though he does his best to be a model, hateful Nazi, JoJo can't overcome his curiosity as he begins learning about Elsa (though he justifies his getting to know her as reconnaissance). He is a boy in search of identity, and though he started finding one in the Hitler Youth movement, it had not been fully baked into his being – Elsa, and his interactions with his friends and leaders of the Hitler Youth, often leave him in a place of contradicting feelings and beliefs as he attempts to reconcile the hate he has learned with the gentle kindness he feels in his heart. Davis and McKenzie sell this journey of self-discovery with ranging performances that brim with sincerity, humor, fear, and hope. They are supported by some great performances from the adults in the cast, particularly Scarlett Johannsen as JoJo's secretly-Nazi-hating mother, Sam Rockwell who portrays the Nazi offer that leads the Hitler Youth, and Waititi as JoJo's imaginary friend, Hitler. It is a bit problematic, especially in our current cultural context, that Nazis are portrayed in such humorous manner, but it's worth noting the undercurrent of devastation and fear that lies hardly beneath the surface, especially whenever we see Elsa come out of the wall, or in some later anxiety-fueling scenes where Nazis come to JoJo's house to find Elsa. Waititi may make rib on some prominent Nazi figures and the absurd cruelty of their ideology, but he never makes light of the horrors that their victims endured. It is that constant shadow of atrocity that grounds this comedy, and what makes JoJo's quest for identity all the more satisfying by film's end. It certainly has Waititi's (arguably, and I'd argue against this characterization) over-the-top stamp on it, but it also has a likeable cast, a good heart, and a message that is in these times certainly worth hearing.

the only thing I knew about Jojo Rabbit prior to watching it was that it had been Oscar-nominated for best picture.

here's my review:

Jojo Rabbit is a fresh, creative take on the WW2 film genre. it conveys a message of love overcoming hate + challenging perspectives, with a clever & darkly funny screenplay that highlights the absurdity + devastation of the Nazi ideology/propaganda/war.

Jojo's charming naïveté and lighthearted moments were a juxtaposition to the heaviness of the subject matter. yet this contrast worked and was full of intentionality,  making the film's message even more impactful. 

vibrant and whimsically-coloured backdrops were a refreshing, visually appealing step away from the dreary colour palette of other WW2 films. the Hitler youth training camp scene in particular reminded me of Wes Anderson's Moonrise Kingdom.

finally, first-time actor Roman Griffin Davis did a wonderful job anchoring the story — his performance successfully managed to make a 10-year-old Nazi boy endearing! Scarlett Johansson and the rest of the cast were great too and they all nailed their German accents (with the exception of Rebel Wilson — but as always, she was cast to provide comedic relief (and she delivered), so she's forgiven). Taika Waititi, the director who also doubled as Hitler, was, dare I say it, fun. 

attempting to make a comedic film about the tragedy of WW2 could have gone wrong in many ways, but Taika defied expectations, presenting us with a stirring blend of sweetness, satire, sobriety & sadness. 

to conclude: I think this is officially one of my favourite films and it's certified fresh 🍅 by me. 😋
